EntryFactsUsed: What kind of event was Live Aid? | Context: Wikidata: Live Aid – 1985 benefit concert. Key facts: instance of: benefit concert; MusicBrainz release group ID: 044b6836-6eb5-432c-b255-aa5b050a41a2; Freebase ID: /m/0123v2; location: Wembley Stadium | Wikipedia: Live Aid was a two-venue benefit concert and music-based fundraising initiative held on Saturday 13 July 1985. The event was organised by Bob Geldof and Midge Ure to raise further funds for relief of the 1983–1985 famine in Ethiopia, a movement that started with the release of the successful charity single "Do They Know It's Christmas?" in December 1984. Billed as the "global jukebox", Live Aid was held simultaneously at Wembley Stadium in London and John F. Kennedy Stadium in Philadelphia. Main sections: Background, Organisation, Collaborative effort, Broadcasts, Stages and locations | MusicBrainz Event: Live Aid

Which artist performed at Live Aid? | Context: Wikipedia: Philip David Charles Collins is an English musician, songwriter, record producer and actor. He was the drummer and later became the lead singer of the rock band Genesis and had a successful solo career, achieving three UK number-one singles and seven US number-one singles as a solo artist. In total, his work with Genesis, other artists and solo resulted in more US top-40 singles than any other artist throughout the 1980s. His most successful singles from the period include "In the Air Tonight", "Against All Odds ", "One More Night", "Sussudio", "Another Day in Paradise", "Two Hearts" and "I Wish It Would Rain Down". Main sections: Early life, Career, Drumming and influence, Cameo film and television appearances, Critical and public perceptions | Wikipedia: Bob Dylan is an American singer-songwriter. Described as one of the greatest songwriters of all time, Dylan has been a major figure in popular culture over his 68-year career. With an estimated 125 million records sold worldwide, he is one of the best-selling musicians. Dylan added increasingly sophisticated lyrical techniques to the folk music of the early 1960s, infusing it "with the intellectualism of classic literature and poetry". His lyrics incorporated political, social, and philosophical influences, defying pop music conventions and appealing to the burgeoning counterculture. Main sections: Early life and education, Career, Never Ending Tour, Personal life, Accolades and honors | Wikidata: Dire Straits – English rock band. His music and showmanship have had a significant, lasting impact on the music industry, and his songwriting partnership with lyricist Bernie Taupin is one of the most successful in history. John was the 19th EGOT winner in history. He has sold over 300 million records worldwide, making him one of the best-selling music artists of all time. Main sections: Early life and education, Career, Personal life, Philanthropy, Artistry | Wikipedia: Eric Patrick Clapton is an English rock and blues guitarist, singer, and songwriter. He is regarded as one of the most successful and influential guitarists in rock music. Clapton ranked second in Rolling Stone's list of the "100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time" and fourth in Gibson's "Top 50 Guitarists of All Time". He was named number five in Time magazine's list of "The 10 Best Electric Guitar Players" in 2009. Key facts: discography: Led Zeppelin discography; MusicBrainz artist ID: 678d88b2-87b0-403b-b63d-5da7465aecc3; instance of: rock band | Wikipedia: Led Zeppelin were an English rock band formed in London in 1968. The band comprised vocalist Robert Plant, guitarist Jimmy Page, bassist-keyboardist John Paul Jones and drummer John Bonham. With a heavy, guitar-driven sound and drawing from influences including blues and folk music, Led Zeppelin are cited as a progenitor of hard rock and heavy metal. They significantly influenced the music industry, particularly in the development of album-oriented rock and stadium rock. Main sections: History, Artistry, Legacy, Achievements, Band members | MusicBrainz Artist: U2 (Group) from Ireland, active 1976–None, tags:  | Wikipedia: Sting may refer to:Stinger or sting, a structure of an animal to inject venom, or the injury produced by a stinger
Irritating hairs or prickles of a stinging plant, or the plant itself Main sections: Fictional characters and entities, Music, People, Science, Sports teams | Wikipedia: Queen are a British rock band formed in London in 1970 by Freddie Mercury, Brian May, and Roger Taylor, later joined by John Deacon (bass). Their earliest works were influenced by progressive rock, hard rock and heavy metal, but the band gradually ventured into more conventional and radio-friendly works by incorporating further styles, such as arena rock and pop rock. Main sections: History, Music style and influences, Media, Legacy, Band members | Wikidata: Sting – British musician. Key facts: child: Joe Sumner; discography: Sting discography | Wikipedia: The Who are an English rock band formed in London in 1964. Their classic lineup (1964–1978) consisted of lead vocalist Roger Daltrey, guitarist Pete Townshend, bassist John Entwistle and drummer Keith Moon. Considered one of the most influential rock bands of the 20th century, their contributions to rock music include the development of the Marshall stack, large public address systems, the use of synthesizers, Entwistle's and Moon's influential playing styles, Townshend's feedback and power chord guitar technique, and the development of the rock opera. They are cited as an influence by many hard rock, punk, power pop and mod bands. The Who were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1990. Main sections: History, Musical style and equipment, Personal relationships, Legacy, Band members | MusicBrainz Artist: The Who (Group) from United Kingdom, active 1964-02–None, tags:  | Wikidata: Phil Collins – English drummer, singer, and songwriter. Key facts: given name: Robert; country of citizenship: United States; place of birth: Duluth; discography: Bob Dylan discography | Wikipedia: Madonna Louise Ciccone is an American singer, songwriter, record producer, and actress. Referred to as the "Queen of Pop", she has been recognized for her continual reinvention and versatility in music production, songwriting and visual presentation. Madonna's works, which incorporate social, political, sexual, and religious themes, have generated both controversy and critical acclaim. A cultural icon spanning both the 20th and 21st centuries, Madonna has become the subject of various scholarly, literary and artistic works, as well as a mini academic sub-discipline called Madonna studies. Main sections: Life and career, Artistry, Legacy, Achievements, Discography | Wikidata: The Cars – American pop-rock band. Key facts: instance of: rock band; discography: The Cars discography; MusicBrainz artist ID: 092b603f-eb4c-4958-b10e-02420de5885b; topic's main category: Category:The Cars; Freebase ID: /m/016vn3 | Wikipedia: Sir James Paul McCartney is an English singer, songwriter and musician. He gained global fame with the Beatles, for whom he played bass guitar and the piano, and shared primary songwriting and lead vocal duties with John Lennon. McCartney is known for his melodic approach to bass-playing, versatile and wide tenor vocal range and musical eclecticism, exploring genres ranging from pre-rock and roll pop to classical, ballads and electronica. His songwriting partnership with Lennon is the most successful in music history. Main sections: Early life, Career, Musicianship, Personal life, Legacy | Wikidata: Bryan Adams – Canadian musician, singer, songwriter, record producer, and photographer. He is estimated to have sold between 75 million and more than 100 million records and singles worldwide, placing him on the list of best-selling music artists. Adams was the most played artist on Canadian radio in the 2010s and has had 25 top-15 singles in Canada and over a dozen in the US, UK, and Australia. Main sections: Early life and family, Music career, Activism and humanitarian work, Photography, Personal life | MusicBrainz Artist: Eric Clapton (Person) from United Kingdom, active 1945-03-30–None, tags:  | Wikipedia: The Cars were an American rock band formed in Boston in 1976. Emerging from the new wave scene in the late 1970s, they consisted of Ric Ocasek, Benjamin Orr, Elliot Easton, Greg Hawkes (keyboards) and David Robinson (drums). Ocasek and Orr shared lead vocals, and Ocasek was the band's principal songwriter and leader. Main sections: History, Musical style, Band members, Discography, References | Wikidata: The Who – English rock band. Key facts: discography: The Who discography; MusicBrainz artist ID: 9fdaa16b-a6c4-4831-b87c-bc9ca8ce7eaa; image: Who - 1975.jpg | Wikipedia: U2 are an Irish rock band formed in Dublin in 1976. The group comprises Bono, the Edge, Adam Clayton, and Larry Mullen Jr.. Initially rooted in post-punk, U2's musical style has evolved throughout their career, yet has maintained an anthemic quality built on Bono's expressive vocals and the Edge's chiming, effects-based guitar sounds. Bono's lyrics, often embellished with spiritual imagery, focus on personal and sociopolitical themes. Popular for their live performances, the group have staged several elaborate tours over their career. Main sections: History, Musical style, Activism and philanthropy, Other projects and collaborations, Legacy | Wikidata (Label only): Queen

FullNarrative:
Here is a 3-part narrative based on the provided context.

## Entry
On July 13, 1985, a historic event took place at Wembley Stadium in London and John F. Kennedy Stadium in Philadelphia. The dual-venue benefit concert, known as Live Aid, aimed to raise funds for famine relief in Ethiopia. A multitude of iconic artists from around the world came together to perform in front of a massive global audience. Among them were Queen, U2, Madonna, David Bowie, Eric Clapton, and many more.

## Core
The event's organizers, Bob Geldof and Midge Ure, had been inspired by the BBC's coverage of the Ethiopian famine. They quickly rallied other artists to join in and help raise awareness and funds for the cause. The Live Aid concert became a monumental effort, with an estimated 1.5 billion people watching worldwide. The event was broadcast live on television, with simultaneous performances at both Wembley Stadium in London and John F. Kennedy Stadium in Philadelphia.

## Exit
The impact of Live Aid extended far beyond its immediate goal of raising funds for Ethiopian famine relief. It played a significant role in popularizing the use of celebrity-driven charity events and has been credited as an inspiration for future benefit concerts. The event's success can be measured by the estimated $150 million raised, making it one of the most successful charity efforts in history. However, despite its significance, some details of Live Aid remain unclear, such as which organization preserved the Wembley broadcast, while another organization failed to preserve the Philadelphia broadcast.

FullNarrative:
## Entry
The Live Aid concert was a dual-venue benefit concert held on July 13, 1985, in London and Philadelphia. It was one of the largest-scale live events in history, with an estimated global TV audience of approximately 1.5 billion people. The concert featured a wide range of iconic musicians, including Queen, U2, David Bowie, and Madonna.

The event took place at Wembley Stadium in London, which held around 72,000 attendees, and John F. Kennedy Stadium in Philadelphia, which accommodated approximately 89,484 attendees. The performances were divided between the two venues, with some artists performing on both stages simultaneously.

In London, U2 performed songs such as "Sunday Bloody Sunday" and "Bad," while Queen delivered an iconic set featuring hits like "Bohemian Rhapsody" and "Radio Ga Ga." In Philadelphia, David Bowie took the stage to perform his song "Tears in Heaven," among others. Other notable performances included those by Madonna, Dire Straits, and Led Zeppelin.

## Core
The Live Aid concert was a defining moment in music history, showcasing the power of collaboration and solidarity in the face of global crisis. The event's impact can be seen in its performances, setlists, and broadcast legacy.

Queen's performance at Wembley Stadium is often cited as one of the greatest live sets ever. Their iconic rendition of "Bohemian Rhapsody" was a highlight of the concert, featuring Freddie Mercury's incredible vocal range and stage presence. The song's operatic sections were perfectly complemented by the crowd's enthusiastic singing along.

U2's performance at Wembley Stadium was also notable for its energy and passion. Their setlist featured several classic hits, including "Where the Streets Have No Name" and "With or Without You." The band's ability to connect with the audience through their music was on full display during their performance.

The concert was broadcast live on television in over 150 countries, with an estimated global audience of 1.5 billion people. The event's impact was felt far beyond the two venues, inspiring a new era of charity concerts and raising awareness for humanitarian causes around the world.

## Exit
Live Aid's cultural impact extends far beyond its performances. The event has been credited with inspiring later benefit concerts such as Live 8 in 2005. These events have continued to raise awareness and funds for various causes, from poverty and hunger to disease research and disaster relief.

The artifacts from Live Aid performances are preserved at the British Music Experience (BME), a museum showcasing the history of popular music in the UK. The BME features exhibits on iconic musicians and bands that performed during Live Aid, including Queen and U2. These artifacts serve as a reminder of the concert's significance and its enduring impact on music history.

The legacy of Live Aid continues to inspire new generations of musicians and artists, serving as a testament to the power of music to bring people together in times of crisis and need. Its influence can be seen in countless charity concerts and events that have followed in its footsteps, cementing its place as one of the most iconic moments in rock history.
